{{BLP sources|date=June 2007}} {{Infobox person | image = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1976|11|1}} | birth_place = [[Charleston, South Carolina]], [[United States|U.S.]] | death_date = | death_place = | othername = | occupation = Actor | yearsactive = 2001 – present | spouse = }}
'''Logan Marshall-Green''' (born November 1, 1976) is an [[United States|American]] actor best known for his roles in ''[[Dark Blue (TV series)|Dark Blue]]'', ''[[The O.C.]]'', ''[[24 (TV series)|24]]'', and ''[[Traveler (TV series)|Traveler]]''.
==Early life== Marshall-Green was born in [[Charleston, South Carolina]] and raised by his mother, Lowry Marshall, in [[Cranston, Rhode Island]]. He has a twin brother named Taylor.
Marshall-Green did his undergraduate studies at the [[University of Tennessee, Knoxville]], where he also wrote for the school newspaper, ''[[The Daily Beacon]]'', as an entertainment writer covering the bar, music, and theater scene. He attended the [[National Theater Institute]] in [[Waterford, Connecticut]] and then went on to earn his Master's in Fine Arts from [[New York University]]'s [[Tisch School of the Arts#Graduate Acting Program | Graduate Acting Program]] at the [[Tisch School of the Arts]]. <ref>{{cite web | author= | title=NYU Graduate Acting Alumni | url=http://gradacting.tisch.nyu.edu/object/ga_alumbios.html | year=2011 | accessdate=2011-12-01}}</ref>
==Acting career== Marshall-Green guest-starred in both ''[[Law & Order: Special Victims Unit]]'' in 2003 and ''[[Law & Order]]'' in 2004, before landing recurring roles on [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox's]] ''[[The O.C.]]'' and ''[[24 (TV series)|24]]''.<ref>[http://www.theatermania.com/content/news.cfm/story/6282 Theater News Interview]</ref>
Marshall-Green received a [[Drama Desk Award]] for his performance in [[Neil LaBute]]'s ''[[The Distance From Here]]'' in 2004. And in 2005 he performed in three separate productions: in June he played an anthropomorphic shark in Adam Bock's ''Swimming in the Shallows''; in August he appeared as Bo Decker in a production of William Inge's classic ''[[Bus Stop (play)|Bus Stop]]''; and in December he was the tragic piano virtuoso Beethoven in the [[Peanuts]] spoof ''[[Dog Sees God: Confessions of a Teenage Blockhead]]''.<ref>[http://www.theatermania.com/content/news.cfm/story/6260 Theater News Review of ''Swimming in the Shallows'']</ref> In 2007, he was cast as the villainous Edmund in the [[Public Theater]] production of ''[[King Lear]]'' starring [[Kevin Kline]] in the title role and directed by [[James Lapine]].
In 2005, Marshall-Green starred in the film ''[[Alchemy (film)|Alchemy]]''. That same year he also starred in the Miramax film ''[[The Great Raid]]''.
Marshall-Green portrayed Tyler Fog in the 2007 ABC television series ''[[Traveler (TV series)|Traveler]]''. He appeared as Paco in the 2007 film, ''[[Across the Universe (film)|Across the Universe]].'' He also starred alongside [[John Ortiz]] and [[Larenz Tate]] in the 2008 television film ''Blue Blood''.
Marshall-Green currently stars as Dean Bendis, an undercover police officer, in a [[black ops]] group of the [[Los Angeles Police Department|LAPD]] headed by [[Dylan McDermott]] in the TNT series ''[[Dark Blue (TV series)|Dark Blue]]''. He also starred along side Richard Gere, Ethan Hawke, Don Cheadle, and Wesley Snipes in the 2010 criminal drama ''[[Brooklyn's Finest]]'' directed by Antoine Fuqua. He played Melvin Panton, a young rookie cop who disagrees with the ways of Richard Gere's character a soon to be retired cop Eddie. Marshall-Green played one of the leads in the Universal Pictures thriller film ''[[Devil (film)|Devil]]''.<ref>[http://www.dreadcentral.com/news/38512/universal-debuts-one-devil-a-trailer Universal Debuts One Devil of a Trailer]</ref>
